question.title: Swing: restrict keyboard focus traversal to specific widgets

fragments.text: the
contains a scrolling
, a

, and a JButton. It's being used to display a EULA, forcing the user to accept its terms before they can use the application. My users complained when I used a modal JDialog, so I'm investigating alternatives.

tricky (wouldn't expect a custom ftp to be overly helpful as it isn't responsible for

informationUnits.rawText: _maybe I did it incorrectly_ - maybe, hard to tell without seeing your code :-) That said, managing the glasspane _is_ tricky (wouldn't expect a custom ftp to be overly helpful as it isn't responsible for mouseEvents), so you might consider to use JLayer (as of jdk7, or JXLayer for jdk6) instead.

.  I'd like to be able to restrict keyboard focus traversal to the components in the
when it's visible.

but returns it to some widget beneath my

fragments.text: As mentioned in my comment, I would probably go for a J/X/Layer - but here's a solution if indeed a custom FTP is the only missing piece in your context.

informationUnits.rawText: As mentioned in my comment, I would probably go for a J/X/Layer - but here's a solution if indeed a custom FTP is the only missing piece in your context.

elements.contents: As mentioned in my comment, I would probably go for a J/X/Layer - but here's a solution if indeed a custom FTP is the only missing piece in your context.

fragments.text: To exclude components from focus traversal, reject them in the accept method of a custom FTP. Below is an example which rejects all components which are not children of the
if the
is visible (note: this is overly simplistic, as it handles direct children only, real-world code must walk up the parent chain until it either hit the glasspane or not)

informationUnits.rawText: To exclude components from focus traversal, reject them in the accept method of a custom FTP. Below is an example which rejects all components which are not children of the glassPane if the glassPane is visible (note: this is overly simplistic, as it handles direct children only, real-world code must walk up the parent chain until it either hit the glasspane or not)

elements.contents: To exclude components from focus traversal, reject them in the accept method of a custom FTP. Below is an example which rejects all components which are not children of the glassPane if the glassPane is visible (note: this is overly simplistic, as it handles direct children only, real-world code must walk up the parent chain until it either hit the glasspane or not)

fragments.text: Perhaps a better option is to use a
to simply swap views rather than a glass pane or dialog since this situation does not seem the best suited for glass pane use. If you use
, you don't have to come up with a kludge (fiddle with focus traversal), to fix the side effects of another kludge (using glass pane for things it wasn't intended to be used for).

informationUnits.rawText: Perhaps a better option is to use a CardLayout to simply swap views rather than a glass pane or dialog since this situation does not seem the best suited for glass pane use. If you use CardLayout, you don't have to come up with a kludge (fiddle with focus traversal), to fix the side effects of another kludge (using glass pane for things it wasn't intended to be used for).

elements.contents: Perhaps a better option is to use a

to simply swap views rather than a glass pane or dialog since this situation does not seem the best suited for glass pane use. If you use CardLayout, you don't have to come up with a kludge (fiddle with focus traversal), to fix the side effects of another kludge (using glass pane for things it wasn't intended to be used for).

fragments.text: If you're not familiar with it, a

will allow you to easily swap components in a GUI, and is often used to swap JPanels that hold complex GUI's that occurs when the user goes from one major program state to another. I think that it would be perfect for your purposes and would prevent you from having to worry about your focus issue.

informationUnits.rawText: If you're not familiar with it, a CardLayout will allow you to easily swap components in a GUI, and is often used to swap JPanels that hold complex GUI's that occurs when the user goes from one major program state to another. I think that it would be perfect for your purposes and would prevent you from having to worry about your focus issue.

elements.contents: If you're not familiar with it, a CardLayout will allow you to easily swap components in a GUI, and is often used to swap JPanels that hold complex GUI's that occurs when the user goes from one major program state to another. I think that it would be perfect for your purposes and would prevent you from having to worry about your focus issue.
